content.description: Start matched on the right hand start of Saranac Sluts. Move right on tiny crimps. Climb the face between the Saranac Crack and Saranac Sluts. Big move to positive crimp, match and move up left to top of the sloping arete. Crack is off.
content.location: On the Saranac Boulder, right of Saranac Sluts and left of the obvious crack.

content.description: Start matched on the lowest good tilted edge. Using good feet, work your way right up the overhanging arete on positive edges to a jug ledge (often covered with dirt). Throw up a heel or toe and mantle over.
content.location: West facing overhanging arete on the House Boulder. to the right around the corner from the Satan Slab.

content.description: Start left hand on a low shallow pinch, right on either one of two connected crimps just under the bulge. Climb up angled edges to a sloping top out on the blunt arete. The first jug out left is ON.
content.location: Walk past the House boulder another fifteen to twenty meters to the next biggest boulder. This is the Saranac Boulder. Climb the blunt Northeast facing arete.

content.description: Follow the obvious crack and crimps alongside the crack to the top of the boulder. Super fun warm up, goes at a sit start.
content.location: Saranac Boulder (Obvious finger crack, right of Saranac Sluts)

content.description: Start right foot on the obvious ledge, left hand on a thin angled edge, right hand on tiny gaston. Stand up and use small crimps and nubbins to ascend the slab. highball.
content.protection: pad or two (safe landing but fairly tall)
content.location: On the first and biggest boulder found when walking down the dirt road (House Boulder). Only ten to twenty meters off the road. To the left around the corner from Get Over It, You Whale.

content.description:
More detailed information on the grades, names, and FAs of these climbs can be found in the Adirondack Park Bouldering guidebook, available at southernadirondackclimber.bâ€¦

  The Cove Boulders are a small series of boulders from house-sized to lowballs found inside the Rogers Rock State Park. Not going to be a destination bouldering spot, but if you're vacationing in the area and itching to pull down, this is worth stopping at. 

  Great relief from the sun in the Summer - well shaded. Bug spray is recommended.  

  Rock is bulletproof for the most part.  Potential for tons of new problems
